"OFF THE TOP OF MY HEAD\
\
A Hand-Book For Hatters\
\
CONTENTS\

8. Senior Apprentice\

11. Artisan\

13. Master\
14. Master Adept\
15. Grand Master\
16. Updates"

"INTRODUCTION\
\
The hat is the ultimate mark of respectability. Hatters are thus the most sought-out clothing providers within the castle. They alone possess the special training required to alter and customize many common types of headwear, including hats and caps of all kinds.\
\
Not all clothing items will succumb to the scissors of a hatter. Shirts, pants, dresses, gowns and the like require the more general skills of a TAILOR. Gloves and handwear are the province of a GLOVER, while hats and headwear are the speciality of the HATTER. An experienced DYER is required to change the color of an item; and the application of custom symbols requires the services of an EMBROIDERER. Hatters are encouraged to consider learning one or more of these crafts as well."

"MATERIAL\
\
Hatters practice their noble artistry upon two of the most fundamental qualities of headwear, MATERIAL and FIT.\
\
The MATERIAL of a headwear item defines its texture and feel, but it also says something about the skill of the maker and taste of the wearer. Over thirty different fabrics are available in Castle Marrach, classified according to rarity and difficulty of working. Novices employ common materials such as burlap or linen, while more experienced artisans use more exotic fabrics including silk, lizardskin or even spun glass!"

"FIT\
\
FIT describes the quality of the relationship between a headwear item and its wearer's head. Novices must work hard to achieve even a crude or awkward fit; but after patient training, the serious student will be able to attain more desireable appearances."

"MEASURES OF PROFICIENCY\
\
Ten levels of proficiency are recognized for the hatting skill:\
\
1. Novice\
2. Junior Apprentice\
3. Senior Apprentice\
4. Fellowcraft\
5. Journeyman\
6. Artisan\
7. Senior Artisan\
8. Master\
9. Master Adept\
10. Grand Master\
\
A Novice hatter possesses very limited ability, and is able to attempt only a few rudimentary alterations. As skill increases, however, many more possibilities become available. A seasoned Master may command dozens of alteration options.\
\
The remainder of this Hand-Book describes the alteration options available to hatters at each level of proficiency."

"NOVICE\
\
Novices are the least experienced hatters. Their effects are admittedly rather limited and uninspiring.\
\
They work in none, burlap, homespun, and linen.\
\
Their hats are crude, awkward, or tasteless."

"JUNIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Junior Apprentices can manage a bit more than Novices, but their additional skills can hardly be called impressive.\
\
They work in canvas, cotton, and gauze.\
\
The fit of their hats is careless, indifferent, or hurried."

"SENIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Senior Apprentices have attained sufficient skill to create a handful of modest but useful styles.\
\
The basic materials of hemp, muslin, and flannel are available to them.\
\
Their efforts result in a fit of adequate, loose, or tight."

"FELLOWCRAFT\
\
Fellowcraft hatters have spent many hours learning their trade, and may apply a personal mark to the hats they create or alter.\
\
Their hats are created from leather, lawn, or brocade.\
\
The fit of their hats might be described as trim, tasteful, or conservative."

"JOURNEYMAN\
\
Journeymen possess the confidence to work with headwear options of significant appeal.\
\
The stylish materials of suede, velveteen, and fur are sometimes employed by these craftsmen.\
\
Hats they create have a fit of attractive, modest, or revealing."

"ARTISAN\
\
Artisans have proven themselves capable of the fine control needed to handle some of the more challenging fabrics and styles.\
\
The difficult materials they employ include calfskin, satin and lace\
\
Their hats are classical, provocative, or flattering."

"SENIOR ARTISAN\
\
Senior Artisans are sought by those desiring rare fabrics and fine cuts for their headwear. They often serve as assistants to Master hatters.\
\
A hat produced by a Senior Artisan might be made from serge, damask, or velour.\
\
The fit of their hats is elegant, cunning, or stylish."

"MASTER\
\
Long careers of study and craftsmanship have given Masters the ability to work with materials and styles of the most rarified quality. They can also alter the material and fit of headwear items that have previously been altered.\
\
The unusual fabrics they work with include lambskin, lizardskin, and silverweave.\
\
the fit of their hats is exquisite, graceful, or beautiful."

"MASTER ADEPT\
\
Master Adepts are usually the supreme experts within the castle upon the art of hatting. They employ particularly splendid fabrics and finishes.\
\
The fabrics they employ include silk, velvet, and goldweave.\
\
Their hats are perfect, immaculate, or sublime."

"GRAND MASTER\
\
Often, many long seasons will pass without a Grand Master of hatting being present within the castle. The skill of these rare people will usually be employed in the service of the Queen and the most favored members of her court.\
\
They work in iridescent, diaphanous, and glassweave.\
\
Their hats have a fit which can only be described as divine."

"UPDATES\
\
As art and fashion changes with the castle, new alterations become available to the hatters. The text of this book will mysteriously update itself as new choices become available. More senior hatters will inform you if and when updates occur.\
\
Please bring typographical errors or other textual problems found in this volume to the attention of the staff."
